meanings.definition: To drink or absorb liquid slowly or in small quantities.
meanings.sent1: She likes to sipple her tea in the morning.
meanings.sent2: I sipple my water throughout the day to stay hydrated.
meanings.sent3: The cat decided to sipple the milk from the bowl with dainty laps.
meanings.sent4: The flowers seemed to sipple the raindrops, quenching their thirst.
meanings.sent5: The child learned to sipple the juice from the straw, enjoying each tiny drop.

meanings.definition: A small quantity of liquid that is sipped.
meanings.sent1: He poured a sipple of wine into his glass.
meanings.sent2: The bartender handed her a sipple of the special cocktail.
meanings.sent3: The tiny sipple of soup left her wanting more.
meanings.sent4: The sipple of honey on the spoon was just enough for the recipe.
meanings.sent5: The sipple of water in the cup was refreshing after the long walk.

meanings.definition: To take small sips of a drink.
meanings.sent1: She would sipple her hot cocoa slowly by the fireplace.
meanings.sent2: He sipple his lemonade while watching the sunset.
meanings.sent3: The bird seemed to sipple the nectar from the flower with delicate sips.
meanings.sent4: The child sipple the juice box, enjoying the sweet taste.
meanings.sent5: The old man would sipple his tea every afternoon, lost in thought.

meanings.definition: A small amount of liquid taken into the mouth with the lips.
meanings.sent1: She took a sipple of the cool water from the fountain.
meanings.sent2: The baby's lips formed a perfect sipple on the bottle.
meanings.sent3: The sipple of milk on the spoon was just enough for the recipe.
meanings.sent4: The sipple of soup warmed her from the inside out.
meanings.sent5: The sipple of coffee in the cup was just what she needed to start the day.
